docs.lead_paragraph: ''Great Feuds in Medicine,'' by Hal Hellman, Wiley, $24.95. In 1761, Dr. Leopold Auenbrugger, a German physician, hit upon a way to read the human body's mysterious inner workings. By rapping a patient's thorax, he found he could listen to the echo from the chest cavity and identify certain conditions by the sound responses.
docs.abstract: BOOKS ON HEALTH: 10 Brutal Battles of Medical Heavyweights**John Langone reviews book Great Feuds in Medicine by Hal Hellman; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite substantial bleeding in his brain, Sam J. Caldrone did not die swiftly. Mr. Caldrone, 83, a retired construction foreman from Pittsburgh, lingered in a coma for almost five weeks after his stroke on Dec. 12, maintained by a ventilator and a feeding tube while his family struggled with the limited possibilities of his future. ''The minute I put my signature on the document to put my father on life support, I was questioning it,'' said Marilyn Schwilm, 45, who is a bartender in Pittsburgh. ''Was it the right decision? Was it what Dad would want? We weren't equipped to make those decisions, and the doctors, as good as they were, didn't help us make them.''

headline.main: Unlikely Guide to End-of-Life Decisions, Computer Eases Way

docs.abstract: Businesses, hospitals and universities are adapting computer technology from video games to market analysis to help families make end-of-life decisions; some computer programs walk users through same kind of decision-making process that business executives use; Internet companies, communities and health care provicers are using computers to ensure instant access to documents like living wills and medical directives, which patients can use to specify which life-prolonging treatments they want; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Epilepsy patients who switch brands of a widely used medication may be at risk of more seizures and toxic side effects, researchers say. Writing in the current issue of Neurology, researchers say they found substantial differences in how the body absorbs different formulas of phenytoin, which is marketed as Dilantin and also available in generic versions and is the most widely used drug for epilepsy.
docs.abstract: Study finds substantial differences in how body absorbs various generic versions of widely used epilepsy drug phenytoin, which is marketed under brand name Dilantin; Dr B J Wilder, study author, warns no substitutions should be made without doctors knowledge, holding there is fine line between amount needed to prevent seizures and amount that can be toxic (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Parents battling to get their children to bed on time can now argue (or plead) that the federal government is on their side. With a new school year beginning, the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute is starting a ''star sleeper'' campaign intended to encourage children to get more sleep.

headline.main: Adding Some Sleep to Children's Agendas

docs.abstract: National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute is starting drive to spur children to get more sleep; urges children age 7 to 11 to get at least nine hours of sleep a night; holds teenagers need just as much sleep (S)
docs.snippet: Parents battling to get their children to bed on time can now argue (or plead) that the federal government is on their side.    With a new school year beginning, the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute is starting a ''star sleeper'' campaign...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ann and Stanley Reese were thrilled last summer when they adopted two toddlers from Romania, Ileana and Traian, and brought them home to Rye, N.Y. But two days later, Ms. Reese noticed that Ileana was limping badly and took her to the emergency room. The doctors determined that Ileana had broken her ankle in two places. Then they delivered the really bad news: she had an advanced case of osteoporosis, a bone-thinning condition that primarily afflicts older people. Unnerved, Ms. Reese called Dr. Jane Aronson, a New York City pediatrician who is an expert on the health problems of children adopted from abroad.

headline.main: Adoption Medicine Brings New Parents Answers and Advice

docs.abstract: Over dozen physicians in United States and Canada are specialists in emerging field of adoption medicine, dealing with unfamiliar health problems of increasing number of children adopted from abroad; offer parents pre-adoption counseling and evaluation and post-adoption consultations; Dr Jane Aronson comments on specialty; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A routine dental exam in some offices can now yield more than just tooth and gum information. Many dental X-rays, a recent study says, can also be used to detect the hardening of the arteries in the neck that can foreshadow a stroke. Writing in The Journal of the American Dental Association, researchers from the Veterans Affairs Greater Los Angeles Healthcare System said the changes were easily noticeable in images captured through panoramic radiography.

headline.main: Dental Exam May Offer Clues on Stroke

docs.abstract: Study finds dental X-rays taken with panoramic X-ray machines can be used to detect hardening of arteries in neck that can foreshadow stroke; Dr Arthur H Friedlander suggests dentists who use machines should be alert to changes in neck so they can refer patients for treatment; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When a patient comes in for help with a rattlesnake bite, doctors are sometimes reluctant to give the common antidote, antivenin, for fear that the drug may prove more dangerous than the rattlesnake's poison. Most bites are not deadly. A new study, however, has found that while antivenin does have side effects, they are rarely serious. Writing in the current issue of The Western Journal of Medicine, Dr. Steven R. Offerman and his colleagues from the University of California at Davis said doctors should not hesitate to use a treatment called polyvalent crotalid antivenin for many patients.
docs.abstract: New study finds doctors should not hesitate to use treatment called polyvalent crotalid antivenin for many rattlesnake bite patients because side effects are rarely serious; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''A Field Guide to Boys and Girls,'' by Susan Gilbert. Harper/Collins, $24. Virtually every parent -- reinforced by a formidable army of nonparents and child psychologists -- has had something authoritative to say about the differences between boys and girls.

headline.main: Boys and Girls: Separating Truth and Myth

docs.lead_paragraph: When you are planning for college, having a baby or coping with a chronic illness like diabetes, you probably seek information and support from printed materials, the Internet, friends and classes. ''But where we really drop the ball is planning for the end of life,'' said Angela Lambing, project manager for the Promoting Excellence in End-of-Life Care program at the Henry Ford Health System in Detroit. ''We don't talk about it or plan for what we want or how we will handle things.''

headline.main: Internet Sites Offer Guidance on Doing the Right Thing for Loved Ones Who Are Dying

docs.abstract: Several well-respected Internet sites offer end-of-life resources for planning to deal with medical, legal, financial and personal issues; some sites noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People with pacemakers and similar devices implanted in their bodies may need to have them removed if they develop staph infections in the blood, a new study warns. The devices, even if they are not the cause of the infection, can harbor potentially life-threatening pathogens that can be impossible to detect when the equipment is in the body, researchers report in the current issue of Circulation, a journal of the American Heart Association.
